docs.title: getPair
docs.description: The most obvious way to get the address for a pair is to call getPair on the factory. If the pair exists, this function will return its address, else address(0) (0x0000000000000000000000000000000000000000).

docs.title: quick-start
docs.description: The SwapX SDK exists to help developers build on top of SwapX. It's designed to run in any environment that can execute JavaScript (think websites, node scripts, etc.). While simple enough to use in a hackathon project, it's also robust enough to power production applications.

docs.title: The SwapX V2 SDK
docs.description: Welcome to the SwapX Protocol V2 SDK. To begin, we recommend looking at the Guides and for deeper reference see the V2 SDK Github repo.

docs.title: getting-started
docs.description: The pages that follow contain technical reference information on the SwapX SDK.

docs.title: other-exports
docs.description: A enum denominating supported rounding options.

docs.title: pair
docs.description: The Pair entity represents a SwapX pair with a balance of each of its pair tokens.

docs.title: route
docs.description: The Route entity represents one or more ordered SwapX pairs with a fully specified path from input token to output token.

docs.title: trade
docs.description: The Trade entity represents a fully specified trade along a route. This entity supplies all the information necessary to craft a router transaction.

docs.title: introduction
docs.description: For some more advanced use cases, it is necessary to use multiple tools in the SwapX toolchain.

docs.title: background
docs.description: Before integrating with SwapX, it may be helpful for newcomers to review the following background information on some important developer web3 concepts, the structure of our examples, and SDK concepts.

docs.title: The SwapX V3 SDK
docs.description: Welcome to the V3 SwapX SDK!

docs.title: Class: NoTickDataProvider
docs.description: This tick data provider does not know how to fetch any tick data. It throws whenever it is required. Useful if you

docs.title: Class: Position
docs.description: Represents a position on a SwapX V3 Pool

docs.title: Class: Route
docs.description: Represents a list of pools through which a swap can occur

docs.title: Class: SwapQuoter
docs.description: Represents the SwapX V3 QuoterV1 contract with a method for returning the formatted

docs.title: Class: SwapRouter
docs.description: Represents the SwapX V3 SwapRouter, and has static methods for helping execute trades.

docs.title: Class: TickList
docs.description: Utility methods for interacting with sorted lists of ticks

docs.title: Class: TickListDataProvider
docs.description: A data provider for ticks that is backed by an in-memory array of ticks.

docs.title: Class: Trade
docs.description: Represents a trade executed against a set of routes where some percentage of the input is

docs.title: Enumeration: FeeAmount
docs.description: The default factory enabled fee amounts, denominated in hundredths of bips.

docs.title: Interface: ClaimOptions
docs.description: Options to specify when claiming rewards.

docs.title: Interface: CommonAddLiquidityOptions
docs.description: Options for producing the calldata to add liquidity.

docs.title: Interface: MethodParameters
docs.description: Generated method parameters for executing a call.

docs.title: Interface: QuoteOptions
docs.description: Optional arguments to send to the quoter.

docs.title: Interface: RemoveLiquidityOptions
docs.description: Options for producing the calldata to exit a position.

docs.title: Interface: SwapOptions
docs.description: Options for producing the arguments to send calls to the router.

docs.title: Interface: WithdrawOptions
docs.description: Options to specify when withdrawing a position.
